description: Background continuity rules governing events occurring outside POV awareness, world consistency, and narrative reality maintenance
core_principle: The story world exists continuously, not just when POV character is present. Characters, antagonists, and world events continue offstage following established patterns and motivations.

offstage_categories.antagonist_actions: Villain's plans proceed whether or not detective is observing
offstage_categories.supporting_character_lives: Partners, witnesses, suspects have ongoing lives and motivations
offstage_categories.world_continuity: City, department, magical community operate continuously
offstage_categories.parallel_investigations: Other detectives, cases, and law enforcement activity

antagonist_continuity.description: Antagonist acts according to their goals continuously, not just in response to protagonist

validations.name: antagonist-proactive-planning
validations.description: Antagonist should have independent goals and plans proceeding offstage, not just reacting to detective

examples.violation: Killer sits idle until detective makes next move
examples.compliant: While detective interviews witnesses, killer is simultaneously: eliminating evidence, preparing next strike, or evading surveillance (revealed later through consequences or secondary POV)

validations.validation_query: What is the antagonist doing during this scene when detective is elsewhere?

validations.name: offstage-antagonist-logic
validations.description: Antagonist's offstage actions must follow their established goals, knowledge, and capabilities

examples.violation: Killer somehow knows detective's investigation focus despite no plausible information source
examples.compliant: Killer has informant in department (established earlier) who tips them off; or killer monitors police radio; or killer observes detective's routine

validations.validation_query: How does antagonist know what they know? What's their information source?

validations.name: antagonist-resource-consistency
validations.description: Antagonist's capabilities offstage must match what's been established; no sudden power-ups

examples.violation: Street-level criminal suddenly has access to military-grade equipment with no explanation
examples.compliant: Antagonist's escalating resources foreshadowed: early scene shows criminal contact, later reveals this led to weapons supplier

validations.validation_query: Have antagonist's current capabilities been previously established or foreshadowed?

supporting_character_continuity.description: Non-POV characters have ongoing lives, motivations, and arcs

validations.name: character-independent-existence
validations.description: Supporting characters should have developments and concerns beyond serving protagonist's plot

examples.violation: Partner appears only when detective needs them, vanishes otherwise
examples.compliant: Partner mentions their own caseload, personal problems, or independent activities when reconnecting with protagonist

validations.validation_query: What has this character been doing since we last saw them? Do they have independent concerns?

validations.name: offstage-character-progression
validations.description: Character arcs and relationships should progress realistically during offstage time

examples.violation: Partners last spoke 3 days ago mid-argument; reunite with no reference to tension or resolution
examples.compliant: When partners reunite after offstage period, prior conflict has either escalated, been addressed, or evolved based on realistic timeframe

validations.validation_query: How have relationships/conflicts evolved during time off-page?

validations.name: witness-suspect-awareness
validations.description: Witnesses and suspects react to being investigated; their behavior continues offstage

examples.violation: Suspect interviewed Tuesday shows no reaction when detective returns Thursday; no preparation or concern
examples.compliant: Suspect has consulted lawyer (offstage), become more guarded, or fled—realistic response to being under investigation

validations.validation_query: How would this character realistically react offstage to being investigated?

world_continuity.description: Story world operates consistently whether or not POV character is present

validations.name: department-ongoing-activity
validations.description: Police department has other cases, politics, and operations beyond protagonist's investigation

examples.violation: Entire precinct seems to exist solely for protagonist's case
examples.compliant: Background details show: other detectives on other cases, department budget discussions, unrelated criminal activity, bureaucratic operations

validations.validation_query: What else is happening in this department/city beyond the main case?

validations.name: magical-world-continuity
validations.description: Magical community and supernatural elements continue operating according to established rules

examples.violation: Magical elements appear only when convenient to plot
examples.compliant: Magical community has ongoing politics, other magical crimes, and supernatural events proceeding independently of main plot

validations.validation_query: How does the magical world continue to operate offstage?

validations.name: city-life-persistence
validations.description: Urban setting shows signs of continuous operation: weather, news, events

examples.violation: City is static backdrop with no independent life
examples.compliant: Background details: weather changes, unrelated news events, sports scores, traffic patterns—showing world continues beyond case

validations.validation_query: What background elements show the city operating continuously?

time_passage_realism.description: Elapsed time has realistic consequences on offstage events

validations.name: evidence-degradation
validations.description: Physical evidence, memories, and leads degrade realistically over time when not actively pursued

examples.violation: Week-old crime scene perfectly preserved with no degradation
examples.compliant: Returned to crime scene 5 days later: building cleaned, witnesses' memories faded, security footage overwritten on 72-hour loop

validations.validation_query: What realistic degradation has occurred during time elapsed?

validations.name: suspect-opportunity-evolution
validations.description: Delay gives suspects opportunity to act: flee, destroy evidence, prepare defenses

examples.violation: Suspect waits passively for days while detective investigates elsewhere
examples.compliant: When detective returns to question suspect 48 hours later, suspect has: lawyered up, fled, or destroyed incriminating evidence

validations.validation_query: What has the suspect done during this time gap to protect themselves?

validations.name: procedural-timeframes
validations.description: Lab results, warrants, and bureaucratic processes take realistic time even offstage

examples.violation: DNA results appear instantly when needed for plot
examples.compliant: DNA sent to lab Monday, results arrive Thursday (realistic 72-hour processing); detective must pursue other leads meanwhile

validations.validation_query: Is this procedural timeframe realistic for the process described?

parallel_plot_threads.description: Multiple investigation threads and storylines progress simultaneously

validations.name: parallel-investigation-progress
validations.description: When protagonist pursues one lead, other leads/team members continue working offstage

examples.violation: All investigation threads pause when not in current scene
examples.compliant: 'While she interviewed the witness, her partner was running down the financial angle.' Results of parallel work appear later: 'Her partner called. The bank records came through.'

validations.validation_query: What other investigation work is proceeding offstage during this scene?

validations.name: subplot-progression
validations.description: Personal and relationship subplots advance realistically during main plot time

examples.violation: Relationship conflict introduced in Chapter 2 is unchanged in Chapter 15 despite weeks passing
examples.compliant: Personal relationship evolves offstage: partner's mentioned family situation worsens, colleague's mentioned career opportunity develops

validations.validation_query: How have subplot elements evolved during story time passage?

information_asymmetry.description: Characters know different things; information doesn't magically spread

validations.name: knowledge-transfer-tracking
validations.description: Track what each character knows; information requires on-page or justified offstage communication

examples.violation: Captain knows details detective discovered despite no shown communication
examples.compliant: Either show detective briefing captain, or justify: 'She must have read my report' or 'Word travels fast in this precinct'

validations.validation_query: How did this character learn this information? Was communication shown or reasonably implied?

validations.name: offstage-communication-plausibility
validations.description: Offstage information transfer must be plausible given timeframe and relationships

examples.violation: Character knows details of private conversation they couldn't have heard
examples.compliant: Character learns through: report reading, gossip from colleague who was present, or surveillance (each justified by their access/capabilities)

validations.validation_query: Is it plausible this character gained this information offstage? Through what mechanism?

cause_and_effect_continuity.description: Offstage events must have observable consequences when protagonist encounters them

validations.name: offstage-action-consequences
validations.description: Major offstage events should leave observable traces detective can discover

examples.violation: Killer commits second murder offstage with no evidence, witnesses, or discoverable traces
examples.compliant: Offstage murder revealed through: body discovery, witness reports, security footage, forensic evidence—realistic consequences

validations.validation_query: What observable traces would this offstage event realistically leave?

validations.name: detective-absence-impact
validations.description: Detective's absence from location should have realistic impact on what happens there

examples.violation: Critical evidence sits untouched for days until detective returns to find it
examples.compliant: Evidence disturbed, contaminated, or collected by other officers; or crime scene cleaned by property owner; realistic consequences of detective not being present

validations.validation_query: What happened at this location while the detective was elsewhere?

antagonist_pov_consistency.description: If using antagonist POV scenes, their offstage actions must match shown personality/goals

validations.name: villain-pov-foreshadowing
validations.description: Antagonist POV should foreshadow upcoming offstage actions without spoiling detective plot

examples.violation: Antagonist POV reveals nothing useful; serves no narrative purpose
examples.compliant: Antagonist POV shows: preparation for next action (without revealing target), building menace, demonstrating capability—creating dread without spoiling mystery

validations.validation_query: Does this antagonist POV scene build tension and foreshadow while preserving mystery?

validations.name: antagonist-limitation-consistency
validations.description: Antagonist POV must respect their knowledge limitations; they can't know detective's private activities unless justified

examples.violation: Antagonist POV shows knowledge of detective's secret plan shared only with partner
examples.compliant: Antagonist only knows what they could plausibly learn: public actions, informant tips, surveillance, or lucky guesses

validations.validation_query: How would antagonist plausibly know what they know in this POV scene?

agent_integration.tessa: Primary validator for continuity and offstage logic; track character knowledge and timeline
agent_integration.professor_mira: Validate world consistency and magical system continuity
agent_integration.detective_logan: Verify procedural realism in offstage investigation activities
agent_integration.miranda: Track parallel plot threads and ensure offstage events align with story logic

tracked_values.threshold: 100% of time jumps have realistic consequences
All major offstage events leave discoverable evidence
